channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden’s Policy Agenda Rests Heavily on Senate Outcome
item.description: Which party controls the Senate will largely dictate how ambitious President-elect Joe Biden can get on taxes, health care, climate change and other policy priorities.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Lynsey Weatherspoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two Democratic candidates, Jon Ossoff, second from left, and the Rev. Raphael G. Warnock, second from right, forced runoffs in elections that will determine which party will control the Senate.

item.title: Biden Names Ron Klain as White House Chief of Staff
item.description: Mr. Klain, a lawyer and veteran Democratic operative who first worked for the president-elect in the late 1980s when he was a senator, has been a sharp critic of President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Katie Glueck, Maggie Haberman and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:description: Ron Klain is known for steady nerves and a fierce wit, which he frequently unleashed on President Trump on Twitter during the campaign.

item.title: G.O.P. Senator Says Biden Should Get Daily Presidential Briefings
item.description: Senator James Lankford said he would “step in” if President-elect Joe Biden did not begin to receive briefings by the end of the week. Catch up on the latest.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Election Showed a Wider Red-Blue Economic Divide
item.description: Some partisan differences were scrambled, but places with brighter future prospects swung toward Biden.
item.dc:creator: Jed Kolko
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s Post-Election Tactics Put Him in Unsavory Company
item.description: Denying defeat, claiming fraud and using government machinery to reverse election results are the time-honored tools of dictators.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: President Trump has shattered a bedrock democratic tradition by raising even the possibility that he would have to be forced from office.

item.title: For Pence, the Future Is Tied to Trump as Much as the Present Is
item.description: If President Trump announces he will run again in 2024, his vice president’s plans could be derailed.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence must balance his loyalty to a president making baseless claims of voter fraud against his own political future and reputation.

item.title: Brad Raffensperger, Georgia's Top Elections Official, Is Under Fire
item.description: After becoming the target of his own party, Brad Raffensperger authorized a hand recount of the state’s presidential votes.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since taking office in January 2019, Brad Raffensperger, Georgia’s secretary of state, has been both a Republican soldier and a target for Democrats in Georgia’s high-stakes voting wars.

item.title: Trump Stacks the Pentagon and Intel Agencies With Loyalists. To What End?
item.description: So far, there is no evidence the appointees harbor a secret agenda or arrived with an action plan. But their sudden appearance amounts to a purge of the Pentagon’s top civilian hierarchy without recent precedent.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: American troops in Afghanistan in 2019. The president has been frustrated by what he sees as the military moving too slowly to fulfill his promise that all troops will be home by Christmas.

item.title: Who Are the Senior Officials at the Pentagon and the N.S.A?
item.description: The arrival of the new officials has prompted concerns. Their backgrounds offer insights into their policies.
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The National Security Agency in Fort Meade, Md.

item.title: An Intramural Republican Fight Breaks Out Over the C.I.A. Director’s Fate
item.description: Frustration about Gina Haspel among some of President Trump’s allies stretches back to the impeachment inquiry, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina Haspel at the Capitol to meet with Senator Mitch McConnell on Tuesday. For weeks, the president has mulled firing her.

item.title: How Some Conservatives Have Switched to Parler, Rumble and Newsmax
item.description: Since the election, millions have migrated to alternative social media and media sites like Parler, Rumble and Newsmax.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Trump rallied in Harrisburg, Pa., on Saturday. Many conservatives have shifted away from Facebook and Twitter since the election.

item.title: Drudge Report, a Former Trump Ally, Looks to Biden
item.description: Matt Drudge and Donald Trump boosted each other four years ago. Now his site says, in prominent type, “The World Moves On.”
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: Matt Drudge’s Drudge Report is looking ahead to a Biden administration. “Dogs will return to White House: Biden’s German shepherds!” said one of its headlines this week.

item.title: After Biden Win, Right-Wing Sites Still Push False Vote-Fraud Claims
item.description: Many publications have refused to acknowledge the president-elect.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu and Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Casting doubt on the integrity of the vote “has been a fundamental part of Trump’s election strategy,” said Whitney Phillips of Syracuse University.

item.title: As U.S. Breaks Hospitalization Records, Many States Add Restrictions
item.description: New York will limit gatherings and require restaurants to close daily at 10 p.m. The Ohio governor issued a mask mandate. Catch up on the latest.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: 19% Positivity Rate as Outbreak Accelerates in N.J.’s Largest City
item.description: After nearly one in five residents who were tested over three days last week were found to have the coronavirus, Newark announced a set of strict new rules.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Armstrong and Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If I touch something, I wash,” said Carlos Ribeiro, a manager of Calandra’s Bakery in Newark. “I support masks 200 percent.”

item.title: How FTI Drove Influence Campaigns Nationwide for Big Oil
item.description: FTI, a global consulting firm, helped design, staff and run organizations and websites funded by energy companies that can appear to represent grass-roots support for fossil-fuel initiatives.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of FTI, which has a prominent role in influence campaigns supporting fossil fuels, in Washington.

item.title: Fall in Love With Sopranos
item.description: Listen to five minutes of Maria Callas, Jessye Norman and others, and you’ll be a fan of the soaring soprano voice. Plus, more ways to pass the time at home.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Children Never Had Covid. So Why Did They Have Coronavirus Antibodies?
item.description: A provocative study suggests that certain colds may leave antibodies against the new coronavirus, perhaps explaining why children are more protected than adults.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: Children may carry antibodies effective against the new coronavirus following infections with related viruses, a new study suggests.

item.title: Stream These Vintage Heist Movies
item.description: Some of the most popular heist films of the last 25 years are remakes of beloved classics. Here’s where you can find the originals.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Birth of the Animal Rights Movement
item.description: Ernest Freeberg talks about “A Traitor to His Species,” and the illustrator Christian Robinson discusses his career in picture books.
item.category: A Traitor to His Species: Henry Bergh and the Birth of the Animal Rights Movement (Book)

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: No More Secrets
item.description: “Honesty is linear.” Relationships require work and redefining, year after year.

item.title: Post-Election Therapy With Esther Perel
item.description: The couples counsellor has some advice for how to heal “the screaming match” in a relationship — and in our nation.

item.title: Pick the Worst of Trump’s Worst
item.description: A plethora of awful alternatives.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins

item.title: New York City Must Hit Pause on Indoor Dining
item.description: City and state officials, with an eye toward keeping schools open, should not wait to impose additional lifesaving restrictions.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Trump’s Election Tantrum
item.description: His latest fit reminds me of a toddler’s. Except 3-year-olds don’t hold the power of the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: When Trump Vandalizes Our Country
item.description: The president should grit his teeth and repeat Hillary Clinton’s line from 2016: “We must accept this result.”
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kristof

item.title: What’s Happening in Ethiopia Is a Tragedy
item.description: Much of the blame must be laid at the door of the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Tsedale Lemma
item.media:description: Militia fighters from Ethiopia’s Amhara region in Tigray, earlier this month. The country stands on the cusp of civil war.

item.title: In the Armenia-Azerbaijan Peace Deal, Great Power Politics Is Back
item.description: Russia and Turkey brokered an end to the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh. But they don’t have the region’s best interests at heart.
item.dc:creator: Thomas De Waal
item.media:description: Azerbaijanis celebrating in the streets of Baku, yesterday.

item.title: ‘Denial and Anger’: Trump and the Republicans
item.description: Readers urge the president to accept defeat (“Grow up. Get over it. Move on.”), and worry about the threat of a coup or replacing electors.
item.media:description: President Trump visited Arlington National Cemetery on Wednesday, his first public appearance since last Thursday.

item.title: What Impact Could the U.S. Election Have on Your Country?
item.description: Opinion wants to hear the international perspective.
item.dc:creator: Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak

item.title: The Presidential Transition Must Go On
item.description: Joe Biden’s team should be given the official go-ahead for the smooth transfer of power.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: What Is Trump Playing At?
item.description: The president’s refusal to concede that he lost the election is taking us into dangerous territory.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall

item.title: Trump Still Has 70 Days to Wreak Havoc Around the World
item.description: Biden wants to undo the chaos Trump has inflicted from the Middle East to China and beyond. It won’t be easy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Malley and Philip H. Gordon

item.title: Meet Maria Bakalova, the Breakout Star of the ‘Borat’ Sequel
item.description: The actress, who plays the title character’s daughter, Tutar, talks about body hair, her “nonbiological father” Sacha Baron Cohen, and that scene with Rudy Giuliani.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bakalova in West Hollywood, Calif. In her native Bulgaria, she was a “super-disciplined” child who hadn’t seen the original “Borat.”

item.title: Tom Hanks on World War II's 75th Anniversary
item.description: Act III of the war — After the War — is now simply part of our daily reality, in America and globally, writes Tom Hanks.
item.dc:creator: Tom Hanks
item.media:credit: Margaret Bourke-White/The Life Picture Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Cyril W. Spiegelhoff of the Archdiocese of Milwaukee leads a group of kneeling American soldiers in prayer in Cologne, Germany, in April 1945.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Loved and Wanted,’ by Christa Parravani
item.description: In “Loved and Wanted,” Christa Parravani gets real about abortion access in West Virginia.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sandler
item.category: Loved and Wanted: A Memoir of Choice, Children, and Womanhood (Book)

item.title: Jeffrey Toobin Is Fired by The New Yorker
item.description: The star journalist exposed himself on a video conference call last month. “We take workplace matters seriously,” a Condé Nast executive said.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:description: Jeffrey Toobin had been a staff writer at The New Yorker since 1993.

item.title: Eta Thrashes Florida, Again
item.description: The storm, which had battered South Florida and parts of Cuba and Central America, brought high winds and tidal surge to the Tampa area as it headed north to make landfall.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales and Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: A lifeguard walks to the end of the jetty after closing it down to surfers before the arrival of Tropical Storm Eta in Bradenton Beach, Florida.

item.title: Would He or Wouldn’t He? Johnson Is Relieved That Biden Called
item.description: The British prime minister made the A team, with Emmanuel Macron and Angela Merkel, though pesky Ireland also sneaked in.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain spoke with President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday.

item.title: Austria’s Leader Seeks Crackdown on Islamist Terrorism After Attack
item.description: Chancellor Sebastian Kurz announced a set of legislative proposals that would make it easier to keep terrorists behind bars, close mosques and clamp down on funding for terrorists.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Chancellor Sebastian Kurz of Austria during a news conference this week in Paris.

item.title: UPS to Allow Natural Black Hairstyles and Facial Hair
item.description: The policy change comes amid a growing national movement to ban racial discrimination based on people’s natural hairstyle.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A UPS driver making a delivery in Brooklyn. The company has eliminated rules against facial hair.

item.title: With Village Beheadings, Islamic State Intensifies Attacks in Mozambique
item.description: The United Nations called for an investigation into reports of many people beheaded in northern Mozambique, where Islamist insurgents have stepped up a brutal campaign.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The aftermath of an attack by Islamist rebels on the village of Aldeia da Paz last year outside Macomia, Mozambique.

item.title: Lucille Bridges, Mother of Civil Rights Trailblazer, Dies at 86
item.description: In 1960, Ms. Bridges enrolled her daughter Ruby in an all-white school in New Orleans and escorted her there, breaking through segregation.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Steve Ueckert/Houston Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Lucille Bridges next to the Norman Rockwell painting “The Problem We All Live With,” which depicts her daughter Ruby being escorted into a New Orleans school.

item.title: Ken Paxton Fought Trump’s Legal Wars From Texas. Now He’s in Trouble.
item.description: The Texas attorney general, who fought against the Affordable Care Act and mail-in voting, has been accused of wrongdoing by his own aides amid calls for his resignation.
item.dc:creator: David Montgomery and Manny Fernandez
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The latest allegations, coming on top of his indictment in 2015 for securities fraud, have created a political crisis for Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas.

item.title: Meet George Jetson? Orlando Unveils Plans for First Flying-Car Hub in U.S.
item.description: The “vertiport” is scheduled to be completed in 2025 in Orlando, which granted more than $800,000 in potential tax rebates to Lilium, a German aviation company that plans to build and operate the hub.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Why Am I Worried? You Should Be.
item.description: Make time for it.
item.dc:creator: Tim Herrera

item.title: Enjoy the Holidays Alone
item.description: Single people make up one third of all American households and finding ways to celebrate this Thanksgiving means taking action ahead of time.
item.dc:creator: Anna Goldfarb

item.title: What to Do When You Can’t Catch a Break
item.description: Researchers say the key to breaking the cycle is to detach yourself from the frustrations you feel — without pretending the pain doesn’t exist.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Wong

item.title: Helping Children With Anxiety in the Pandemic
item.description: Even in an anxious time, children’s anxiety is treatable.
item.dc:creator: Perri Klass, M.D.
item.media:description: “Bedtime is a lovely time,” one expert says, “but not the best time to have lengthy conversations about things that are on your kid’s mind.”

item.title: Help! Where Is the Safest Seat on an Airplane?
item.description: Deciding where to sit on a plane has always been an exercise in strategy and skill: how to get the most legroom, the best shut-eye, the quickest exit. The stakes certainly feel higher now.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Firshein

item.title: In the Arctic, Reindeer Are Sustenance and a Sacred Presence
item.description: For the Indigenous communities who herd the animals, safeguarding dying culinary traditions isn’t merely about eating but about protecting a longstanding way of life.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan

item.title: How Hyperpop, a Small Spotify Playlist, Grew Into a Big Deal
item.description: The microgenre — fueled by teen upstarts like osquinn and glaive, and more established names like 100 gecs and A.G. Cook — has a modest but dedicated following, and many different kinds of sounds.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dandridge-Lemco
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 15-year-old artist osquinn, who has also recorded as P4rkr, saw her song “Bad Idea” take off on Spotify’s Hyperpop playlist, and beyond.

item.title: Who Was Pappy Van Winkle and Why Does His Whiskey Cost So Much?
item.description: Wright Thompson’s “Pappyland” goes deep into Kentucky’s bourbon culture through a history of one of its prominent producer families.
item.dc:creator: J. D. Biersdorfer
item.category: Pappyland: A Story of Family, Fine Bourbon, and the Things That Last (Book)
item.media:description: Bottles of Pappy Van Winkle bourbon on display in a liquor store in New York City. In “Pappyland,” Wright Thompson “comes off as the Boswell of bourbon country — a keen literary observer and respectful fanboy with an obvious affection for his subject.”

item.title: A Tough Call for Families: How to Spend Thanksgiving
item.description: If you’re feeling pressured, here are a few ways to keep the peace.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: The Hard Part Is Still to Come for the N.B.A.
item.description: Managing life in a bubble was far from easy, but the N.B.A. is about to experience life in the real world.
item.dc:creator: Marc Stein
item.media:description: The N.B.A. was able to keep its players safe by investing heavily in a bubble environment at Walt Disney World in Florida. Finding the same success in the 2020-21 season will be difficult.

item.title: Mink and the Coronavirus: What We Know
item.description: Mink are the only animal known to both catch the virus from people and transmit it to them.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: Mink on a farm in Bording, Denmark, where the government has ordered all mink culled.

item.title: Could Listening to the Deep Sea Help Save It?
item.description: In the abyss, everyone can hear you scream.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:description: Tube worms cover a sulfide chimney deep underwater in the Pacific Ocean.

item.title: How Some Skinks Lost Their Legs and Then Evolved New Ones
item.description: The lizards have complicated a rule of thumb that in evolution, once you lose a body part, you don’t regain it.
item.dc:creator: Veronique Greenwood
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)
item.media:description: Some skinks, like Brachymeles boulengeri, have more developed limbs with five fingers and toes.

item.title: Shot to Prevent H.I.V. Works Better Than Daily Pill in Women
item.description: Researchers ended a clinical trial of the drug early because the results were so convincing. The more effective drug would be given in six injections a year instead of as 365 daily pills.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Stephane de Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A clinic in South Africa introduces a new H.I.V. treatment in 2013. On Monday, researchers reported that a shot given every two months is effective in preventing H.I.V. in women.

item.title: Biden Wins Presidency, Ending Four Tumultuous Years Under Trump
item.description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. achieved victory offering a message of healing and unity. He will return to Washington facing a daunting set of crises.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
item.media:description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris addressed the nation from Wilmington, Del., on Saturday.

item.title: Florida Principal Who Wouldn’t Call Holocaust ‘Factual’ Is Fired Again
item.description: William Latson was fired last year after an email exchange about staying “politically neutral” about Holocaust education became public. After being rehired last month, he was fired again on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.category: Spanish River Community High School (Boca Raton, Fla)

item.title: Want to Live Near the Shore? Here Are Six Emerging Areas
item.description: There are destinations around the world that home buyers are just discovering.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora
item.media:description: Port d’Andratx is a fishing village on the southwest coast of Majorca. Its beaches tend to be rocky.

item.title: Spelling Bee
item.description: Puzzle throughout the day to see how many words you can find.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Crossword, the Mini and More
item.description: Solve the daily puzzle edited by Will Shortz, or try out other games like the Mini and Letter Boxed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Tiles
item.description: Our soothing matching game may help you de-stress.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
